data.title: Clash of Code Cheater Detection
data.solution:
clasher_name = gets.chomp
solution_time = gets.to_i
n = gets.to_i
comments = 0
n.times do
  code = gets.chomp
  if code =~ /^ *(#(?!include)|\/[\/\*])/
    comments += 1
  end
end
if solution_time < 90 && comments >= 5
  puts clasher_name + " is a cheater!"
else
  puts clasher_name + " gets a pass."
end
puts comments
data.statement:
You've noticed a lot of cheaters submitting AI-generated code for <<Clash of Code>>.

You need to write a tool to detect AI-generated code in Clash submissions.

You are given [[clasher_name]], an integer [[solution_time]] (in seconds), an integer [[n]], and then [[n]] lines of [[code]], determine if the code is AI-generated or not.

<<Your 2 criteria are:>> (cheating detected if <<both>> are true)
- The [[solution_time]] is <<less than 90>> seconds
- The code has <<5 or more comments>> (lines beginning with either {{#}}, {{//}} or {{/*}}

<<Note 1:>> If a line starts with {{#include}} then it <<does not count>> as a comment.
<<Note 2:>> Only count a line as a comment if it <<starts>> with the above symbols (ignore inline comments).
<<Note 3:>> You should <<ignore leading spaces>> when determining if a line starts with a comment symbol.


If cheating is detected, print [[clasher_name]] {{is a cheater!}}. Otherwise, print [[clasher_name]] {{gets a pass.}}. In both cases, also print the number of comments found.

testCases.title: HonestDan

60
7

testCases.title: rinas_shbn
testCases.testIn:
rinas_shbn
18
16
# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.
low, high = map(int, input().split())
temperature = float(input())

# Check if the temperature is in Kelvin
if low <= temperature <= high:
    result = int(temperature)
# Check if the temperature is in Celsius
elif low <= (temperature + 273.15) <= high:
    result = int(temperature + 273.15)
# Check if the temperature is in Fahrenheit
elif low <= (temperature + 459.67) * (5/9) <= high:
    result = int((temperature + 459.67) * (5/9))
# Print the result
print(result)

testCases.title: Aronse
Validator 3
igyxvan
testCases.testIn:
igyxvan
45
28
# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.

K = int(input())
Q = list(map(int, input().split()))

# Sort amounts descending for easier calculation
Q.sort(reverse=True)

days = 0
while True:
    needed = days + 1  # n biscuits on nth day
    available_types = 0
    # Count how many types have at least one left
    for i in range(K):
        if Q[i] > 0:
            available_types += 1
    if available_types < needed:
        break
    # Deduct 1 from the largest-needed types
    used = 0
    for i in range(K):
        if Q[i] > 0 and used < needed:
            Q[i] -= 1
            used += 1
    days += 1
# Print the output
print(days)

testCases.title: Validator 4
testCases.testIn:
neo.hrtns
22
22
# Lecture des entrées
low, high = map(int, input().split())
temperature = float(input())

# Vérification de l'unité de la température
if temperature < 1000:  # Hypothèse: les températures inférieures à 1000 sont probablement en Celsius ou Fahrenheit
    # Température en Celsius
    kelvin = temperature + 273.15
elif temperature > 500:  # Hypothèse: les températures très élevées sont probablement en Kelvin
    kelvin = temperature
else:  # Température en Fahrenheit
    kelvin = (temperature + 459.67) * (5/9)

# Arrondir à l'entier inférieur
kelvin = int(kelvin)

# Vérification si la température est dans la plage
if low <= kelvin <= high:
    print(kelvin)
else:
    # Si elle est hors de la plage, afficher la température à l'intérieur de la plage
    print(max(low, min(kelvin, high)))

end

    # Destroy all pirates
    pirates.delete(i)
  end

data.constraints:
[[clasher_name]] may contain any characters other than spaces.
0 < [[solution_time]] ≤ 900
1 < [[n]] < 70
data.stubGenerator:
read clasherName:string(20)
read solutionTime:int
read n:int
loop n read code:string(200)
write clasher_name is a cheater!/gets a pass.
write number of comments found

STATEMENT
Catch the cheaters!
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1 :>> [[clasher_name]], the name of the clasher who submitted the code
<<Line 2 :>> [[solution_time]], the number of seconds in which the code was submitted
<<Line 3 :>> [[n]], the number of lines of [[code]]
<<Next [[n]] lines :>> strings of [[code]]
data.outputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Either [[clasher_name]] {{is a cheater!}} or  [[clasher_name]] {{gets a pass.}}
<<Line 2:>> The number of comments found.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You've noticed a lot of cheaters submitting AI-generated code for Clash of Code.

You need to write a tool to detect AI-generated code in Clash submissions.

You are given clasher_name, an integer solution_time (in seconds), an integer n, and then n lines of code, determine if the code is AI-generated or not.

Your 2 criteria are: (cheating detected if both are true)
- The solution_time is less than 90 seconds
- The code has 5 or more comments (lines beginning with either #, // or /*

Note 1: If a line starts with #include then it does not count as a comment.
Note 2: Only count a line as a comment if it starts with the above symbols (ignore inline comments).
Note 3: You should ignore leading spaces when determining if a line starts with a comment symbol.


If cheating is detected, print clasher_name is a cheater!. Otherwise, print clasher_name gets a pass.. In both cases, also print the number of comments found.
Input
Line 1 : clasher_name, the name of the clasher who submitted the code
Line 2 : solution_time, the number of seconds in which the code was submitted
Line 3 : n, the number of lines of code
Next n lines : strings of code
Output
Line 1: Either clasher_name is a cheater! or clasher_name gets a pass.
Line 2: The number of comments found.
Constraints
clasher_name may contain any characters other than spaces.
0 < solution_time ≤ 900
1 < n < 70
Example
Input
HonestDan
60
7
# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.
x = int(input())
y = int(input())
# Write an answer using puts
# To debug: STDERR.puts "Debug messages..."
print(x*y**2)
Output
HonestDan gets a pass.
4
